title: Herbert Shoubridge
text:
<a href="Major-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Major General</a> (Thomas) Herbert Shoubridge <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">CB</a>, <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">CMG</a>, <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> (1871 – 1923) was a <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer who became <a href="List%20of%20Governors%20and%20Commandants%20of%20Sandhurst">Commandant of the Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>.
Military career.
Shoubridge was <a href="Officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">commissioned</a> into the <a href="Dorset%20Regiment">Dorset Regiment</a> as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> on 5 March 1893. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> on 18 June 1896, and took part in the <a href="Tirah%20Campaign">Tirah expedition</a> to the <a href="North-West%20Frontier%20%28military%20history%29">North West Frontier</a> of <a href="British%20Raj">India</a> in 1897. Following the outbreak of the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> in late 1899, he became deputy assistant adjutant general for the Natal Army. He transferred to the <a href="Royal%20Northumberland%20Fusiliers">Northumberland Fusiliers</a> and was promoted <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> on 9 May 1900, and received a <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> promotion as <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> dated 29 November 1900 in the South African Honours list of 1901. After the war ended in June 1902, he became Deputy Assistant Quartermaster General at Headquarters, South Africa Command. He was appointed <a href="brigade%20major">brigade major</a> for the <a href="13th%20Infantry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">13th Brigade</a> in 1906 and then served as a general staff officer with <a href="Western%20Command%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Western Command</a> and then <a href="Southern%20Command%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Southern Command</a>.
He fought in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> as assistant adjutant and quartermaster general for <a href="II%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">2nd Army Corps</a> from 1914 and as assistant quartermaster general for <a href="IV%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">4th Army Corps</a> from 1915. He was appointed Commander of <a href="54th%20Infantry%20Brigade%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">54th Infantry Brigade</a> in France later that year. He went on to be General Officer Commanding <a href="7th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">7th Infantry Division</a> in 1917 and General Officer Commanding of <a href="42nd%20%28East%20Lancashire%29%20Infantry%20Division">42nd (East Lancashire) Infantry Division</a> from 1919 and was then briefly <a href="List%20of%20Governors%20and%20Commandants%20of%20Sandhurst">Commandant of the Royal Military College Sandhurst</a> in 1923 before his resignation due to ill health. He lived at Lawrenny Castle near <a href="Kilgetty">Kilgetty</a> in <a href="Pembrokeshire">Pembrokeshire</a>.
Family.
In 1910 he married Constance Gladys Dugdale; they had a daughter and a son.
